additionalTextInformation.text:
A woodcut by Albrecht Dürer from the 'Großen Passion'  (1510) served as the prototype for the composition as well as many of the details. 
[Harasimowicz, Kulisz, in: Harasimowicz, Seyderhelm  2015, 179, 180]

pageContext.description:
The panel depicts the resurrection of Christ. The scene takes place on the top of a mountain, beyond a city is visible, which can be clearly identified as Rome. Christ stands at the centre of the image on top of a closed, rectangular sarcophagus, holding the victory flag and raising his right hand in blessing. He is surrounded by watchmen, some still sleeping - seven men in contemporary armour. His transparent rod is crowned with a gold cross and his cloak is red with a decorative golden border. In the distance on the left three women can be seen approaching from the city. 
[Harasimowicz, Kulisz, in: Harasimowicz, Seyderhelm  2015, 179, 180]
pageContext.dimensions:
Dimensions of support: 150 x 100 x 2.5 cm
[Harasimowicz, Kulisz, in: Harasimowicz, Seyderhelm  2015, 179]
pageContext.inscription:
The epitaph originally had a silver and gold leaf gilded frame, which was decorated with coats of arms. The documented inscription was probably located on the pedestal:
'EPITAPHIVM GENEROSO DOMINO; DOMINO GREGORIO; BARONI A
LAMBERGK* ET DOMINO IN SAUSTEIN,
HAUGSSDORF ET MANPREISS:*
SCRIPTVM A COGNATO DOMINO HENRICO DOMINO*
A STARENPERG*
ET DOMINO* IN WILDPERG*

QVEM FLORERE VIDIE HODIE, CRAS OCCIDIT ILLE.*
QVID SVMVS AH MISERI, PVLVIS ET VMBRA SVMVS.
PVLVIS ET VMBRA SVMVS; METAM PROPERAMVS AD VNAM.*
QVI BENE DESIERIT VIVERE, SALVVS ERIT.
SIC QVOQ[ue] GREGORIVM LVMEN VITALE RELIQVIT,*
QVI LAMBERGIACO SANGVINE NATVS ERAT.
VIVVS AD AETHEREAM MIGRAVIT SPIRITVS ARCEM,*
EIVS IN HOC TVMVLO MOLLITER OSSA CVBANT.'

[Harasimowicz, Kulisz, in: Harasimowicz, Seyderhelm  2015, 179]

metadata.title: Epitaph for Gregor, Baron of Lamberg: The Resurrection

pageContext.provenance:
- on the second south pillar in the choir, close to the grave 
- it is recorded here in the 17th century, then the frame and accompanying inscription were lost 
- the painting survived and in 1928 it was incorporated into the first world war memorial in the west entrance; it has remained here 
[Harasimowicz, Kulisz, in: Harasimowicz, Seyderhelm  2015, 179]
